block.p: Music for the Animals TODAY -- A chamber music concert with musicians from the New York Philharmonic at Christ and St. Stephen's Church, 120 West 69th Street, will benefit the Artemis Project, which pays for spaying and neutering stray animals and for other veterinary services. The concert begins at 3. Suggested donation is $20. Information from: (917)648-6020.

Helping the Homeless TOMORROW -- Peter Jennings and Lauren Hutton will be the hosts of an art auction and dinner at Sotheby's to support the Coalition for the Homeless. The evening begins at 6:30 with cocktails and hors d'oeuvres. Dinner will follow at 7:30 with an auction at about 8:30 of works by Richard Avedon, Louise Bourgeois, Jenny Holzer, Ed Ruscha and others. Tickets, $500, from (212)608-5999.

Fighting Lupus TOMORROW -- A black-tie dinner at the New York Marriott Marquis will aid the S.L.E. Lupus Foundation, which supports research, treatment and public education programs. Drinks at 6 and dinner at 7:30, with dancing to the music of John Pizzarelli and his band and the Loren Schoenberg Big Band. Tickets, $650, from (212)685-4118.

To Preserve History TOMORROW -- Robert E. Rubin will be honored at a black-tie dinner at the New-York Historical Society to celebrate the organization's bicentennial and to benefit its educational and research programs. Drinks and the current Alexander Hamilton exhibition at 6, with a preview of an exhibition of artifacts from the Beekman family. At 7:15, a new film by Ric Burns, on the organization's bicentennial, will premiere. Dinner is at 7:45, with dessert and dancing to the music of the Peter Duchin Orchestra at 9. Tickets, $1,000, or $200 for dessert and dancing only, from (212)873-3400, ext. 297.

Asian-American Theater TOMORROW -- An evening of performances by actors from Broadway at the new Jazz at Lincoln Center performance space will raise money for future performances of Second Generation, an Asian-American theater company, and for its cultural and education programs, including one that attracts Asian-American children from New York neighborhoods and trains them to perform in its children's choir. The evening begins at 6 with a cocktails and hors d'oeuvres reception, with the show at 7:30 and a post-concert reception with the artists about 9:15. Tickets, $250, or $100 for the show only, from (212)334-4777.

For Elderly Manhattanites NOV. 29 -- The Burden Center for the Aging will celebrate its 25th anniversary dinner at the Rainbow Room to aid social service programs for elderly Manhattan residents. Drinks at 7 and dinner at 8, with dancing to the music of the George Young Orchestra. Tickets, $500, from (212)879-7400, ext. 204.

Fighting Drug Abuse NOV. 29 -- Tom Brokaw will be honored at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria to aid the Partnership for a Drug-Free America and its work to reduce illicit drug use through public service announcements and public education. Drinks at 6:30 and dinner and dancing at 7:30, Tickets, $1,000, from (212)973-3533.

Music for the Animals TODAY -- A chamber music concert with musicians from the New York Philharmonic at Christ and St. Stephen's Church, 120 West 69th Street, will benefit the Artemis Project, which pays for spaying and neutering stray animals and for other veterinary services.
